text: the place.--Emma only might be as nature prompted , and shew herself just as happy as she was .
text_tokenized: the place.--Emma only might be as nature prompted , and shew herself just as happy as she was .

text: To her it was real enjoyment to be with the Westons .
text_tokenized: To her it was real enjoyment to be with the Westons .

text: Mr. Weston was a great favourite , and there was not a creature in the world to whom she spoke with such unreserve , as to his wife ; not any one , to whom she related with such conviction of being listened to and understood , of being always interesting and always intelligible , the little affairs , arrangements , perplexities , and pleasures of her father and herself . She could tell nothing of Hartfield , in which Mrs. Weston had not a lively concern ; and half an hour 's uninterrupted communication of all those little matters on which the daily happiness of private life depends , was one of the first gratifications of each .
text_tokenized: Mr. Weston was a great favourite , and there was not a creature in the world to whom she spoke with such unreserve , as to his wife ; not any one , to whom she related with such conviction of being listened to and understood , of being always interesting and always intelligible , the little affairs , arrangements , perplexities , and pleasures of her father and herself . She could tell nothing of Hartfield , in which Mrs. Weston had not a lively concern ; and half an hour 's uninterrupted communication of all those little matters on which the daily happiness of private life depends , was one of the first gratifications of each .

text: This was a pleasure which perhaps the whole day 's visit might not afford , which certainly did not belong to the present half - hour ; but the very sight of Mrs. Weston , her smile , her touch , her voice was grateful to Emma , and she determined to think as little as possible of Mr. Elton 's oddities , or of any thing else unpleasant , and enjoy all that was enjoyable to the utmost

text: The misfortune of Harriet 's cold had been pretty well gone through before her arrival . Mr. Woodhouse had been safely seated long enough to give the history of it , besides all the history of his own and Isabella 's coming , and of Emma 's being to follow ,

text: had indeed just got to the end of his satisfaction that James should come and see his daughter , when the others appeared , and Mrs. Weston , who had been almost wholly engrossed by her attentions to him , was able to turn away and welcome her dear Emma .
text_tokenized: had indeed just got to the end of his satisfaction that James should come and see his daughter , when the others appeared , and Mrs. Weston , who had been almost wholly engrossed by her attentions to him , was able to turn away and welcome her dear Emma .

text: Emma 's project of forgetting Mr. Elton for a while made her rather sorry to find , when they had all taken their places , that he was close to her . The difficulty was great of driving his strange insensibility towards Harriet , from her mind , while he not only sat at her elbow , but was continually obtruding his happy countenance on her notice , and solicitously addressing her upon every occasion .
text_tokenized: Emma 's project of forgetting Mr. Elton for a while made her rather sorry to find , when they had all taken their places , that he was close to her . The difficulty was great of driving his strange insensibility towards Harriet , from her mind , while he not only sat at her elbow , but was continually obtruding his happy countenance on her notice , and solicitously addressing her upon every occasion .

text: Instead of forgetting him , his behaviour was such that she could not avoid the internal suggestion of " Can it really be as my brother imagined ? can it be possible for this man to be beginning to transfer his affections from Harriet to me?--Absurd and insufferable!"-- Yet he would be so anxious for her being perfectly warm , would be so interested about her father , and so delighted with Mrs. Weston ; and at last would begin admiring her drawings with so much zeal and so little knowledge as seemed terribly like a would - be lover , and made it some effort with her to preserve her good manners .
text_tokenized: Instead of forgetting him , his behaviour was such that she could not avoid the internal suggestion of " Can it really be as my brother imagined ? can it be possible for this man to be beginning to transfer his affections from Harriet to me?--Absurd and insufferable!"-- Yet he would be so anxious for her being perfectly warm , would be so interested about her father , and so delighted with Mrs. Weston ; and at last would begin admiring her drawings with so much zeal and so little knowledge as seemed terribly like a would - be lover , and made it some effort with her to preserve her good manners .

text: For her own sake she could not be rude ; and for Harriet 's , in the hope that all would yet turn out right , she was even positively civil ; but it was an effort ; especially as something was going on amongst the others , in the most overpowering period of Mr. Elton 's nonsense , which she particularly wished to listen to .
text_tokenized: For her own sake she could not be rude ; and for Harriet 's , in the hope that all would yet turn out right , she was even positively civil ; but it was an effort ; especially as something was going on amongst the others , in the most overpowering period of Mr. Elton 's nonsense , which she particularly wished to listen to .

text: She heard enough to know that Mr. Weston was giving some information about his son ; she heard the words " my son , " and " Frank , " and " my son , " repeated several times over ; and , from a few other half - syllables very much suspected that he was announcing an early visit from his son ; but before she could quiet Mr. Elton , the subject was so completely past that any reviving question from her would have been awkward .
text_tokenized: She heard enough to know that Mr. Weston was giving some information about his son ; she heard the words " my son , " and " Frank , " and " my son , " repeated several times over ; and , from a few other half - syllables very much suspected that he was announcing an early visit from his son ; but before she could quiet Mr. Elton , the subject was so completely past that any reviving question from her would have been awkward .

text: Now , it so happened that in spite of Emma 's resolution of never marrying , there was something in the name , in the idea of Mr. Frank Churchill , which always interested her .
text_tokenized: Now , it so happened that in spite of Emma 's resolution of never marrying , there was something in the name , in the idea of Mr. Frank Churchill , which always interested her .

text: She had frequently thought -- especially since his father 's marriage with Miss Taylor -- that if she _ were _ to marry , he was the very person to suit her in age , character and condition .
text_tokenized: She had frequently thought -- especially since his father 's marriage with Miss Taylor -- that if she _ were _ to marry , he was the very person to suit her in age , character and condition .

text: He seemed by this connexion between the families , quite to belong to her . She could not but suppose it to be a match that every body who knew them must think of . That Mr. and Mrs. Weston did think of it , she was very strongly persuaded ; and though not meaning to be induced by him , or by any body else , to give up a situation which she believed more replete with good than any she could change it for , she had a great curiosity to see him , a decided intention of finding him pleasant , of being liked by him to a certain degree , and a sort of pleasure in the idea of their being coupled in their friends ' imaginations . With such sensations , Mr. Elton 's civilities were dreadfully ill - timed ; but she had the comfort of appearing very polite , while feeling very cross -- and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not possibly pass without bringing forward the same information again , or the substance of it , from the open - hearted Mr. Weston.--So it proved;--
text_tokenized: He seemed by this connexion between the families , quite to belong to her . She could not but suppose it to be a match that every body who knew them must think of . That Mr. and Mrs. Weston did think of it , she was very strongly persuaded ; and though not meaning to be induced by him , or by any body else , to give up a situation which she believed more replete with good than any she could change it for , she had a great curiosity to see him , a decided intention of finding him pleasant , of being liked by him to a certain degree , and a sort of pleasure in the idea of their being coupled in their friends ' imaginations . With such sensations , Mr. Elton 's civilities were dreadfully ill - timed ; but she had the comfort of appearing very polite , while feeling very cross -- and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not possibly pass without bringing forward the same information again , or the substance of it , from the open - hearted Mr. Weston.--So it proved;--

text: for when happily released from Mr. Elton , and seated by Mr. Weston , at dinner , he made use of the very first interval in the cares of hospitality , the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton , to say to her , " We want only two more to be just the right number .
text_tokenized: for when happily released from Mr. Elton , and seated by Mr. Weston , at dinner , he made use of the very first interval in the cares of hospitality , the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton , to say to her , " We want only two more to be just the right number .

text: I should like to see two more here,--your pretty little friend , Miss Smith , and my son -- and then I should say we were quite complete . I believe you did not hear me telling the others in the drawing - room that we are expecting Frank .
text_tokenized: I should like to see two more here,--your pretty little friend , Miss Smith , and my son -- and then I should say we were quite complete . I believe you did not hear me telling the others in the drawing - room that we are expecting Frank .

text: I had a letter from him this morning , and he will be with us within a fortnight . "
text_tokenized: I had a letter from him this morning , and he will be with us within a fortnight . "

text: Emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure ; and fully assented to his proposition of Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Smith making their party quite complete .
text_tokenized: Emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure ; and fully assented to his proposition of Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Smith making their party quite complete .

text: " He has been wanting to come to us , " continued Mr. Weston , " ever since September : every letter has been full of it ; but he can not command his own time .
text_tokenized: " He has been wanting to come to us , " continued Mr. Weston , " ever since September : every letter has been full of it ; but he can not command his own time .

text: He has those to please who must be pleased , and who ( between ourselves ) are sometimes to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices .
text_tokenized: He has those to please who must be pleased , and who ( between ourselves ) are sometimes to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices .

text: But now I have no doubt of seeing him here about the second week in January .
text_tokenized: But now I have no doubt of seeing him here about the second week in January .

text: " " What a very great pleasure it will be to you !
text_tokenized: " " What a very great pleasure it will be to you !

text: and Mrs. Weston is so anxious to be acquainted with him , that she must be almost as happy as yourself . " " Yes , she would be , but that she thinks there will be another put - off .
text_tokenized: and Mrs. Weston is so anxious to be acquainted with him , that she must be almost as happy as yourself . " " Yes , she would be , but that she thinks there will be another put - off .

text: She does not depend upon his coming so much as I do : but she does not know the parties so well as I do .
text_tokenized: She does not depend upon his coming so much as I do : but she does not know the parties so well as I do .

text: The case , you see , is--(but this is quite between ourselves : I did not mention a syllable of it in the other room .
text_tokenized: The case , you see , is--(but this is quite between ourselves : I did not mention a syllable of it in the other room .

text: There are secrets in all families , you know)--The case is , that a party of friends are invited to pay a visit at Enscombe in January ; and that Frank 's coming depends upon their being put off . If they are not put off , he can not stir .
text_tokenized: There are secrets in all families , you know)--The case is , that a party of friends are invited to pay a visit at Enscombe in January ; and that Frank 's coming depends upon their being put off . If they are not put off , he can not stir .

text: But I know they will , because it is a family that a certain lady , of some consequence , at Enscombe , has a particular dislike to : and though it is thought necessary to invite them once in two or three years , they always are put off when it comes to the point .
text_tokenized: But I know they will , because it is a family that a certain lady , of some consequence , at Enscombe , has a particular dislike to : and though it is thought necessary to invite them once in two or three years , they always are put off when it comes to the point .

text: I have not the smallest doubt of the issue .
text_tokenized: I have not the smallest doubt of the issue .

text: I am as confident of seeing Frank here before the middle of January , as I am of being here myself : but your good friend there ( nodding towards the upper end of the table ) has so few vagaries herself , and has been so little used to them at Hartfield , that she can not calculate on their effects , as I have been long in the practice of doing .

text: " " I am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case , " replied Emma ; " but am disposed to side with you , Mr. Weston .
text_tokenized: " " I am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case , " replied Emma ; " but am disposed to side with you , Mr. Weston .

text: If you think he will come , I shall think so too ; for you know Enscombe .
text_tokenized: If you think he will come , I shall think so too ; for you know Enscombe .

text: " Yes -- I have some right to that knowledge ; though I have never been at the place in my life.--She is an odd woman!--But
text_tokenized: " Yes -- I have some right to that knowledge ; though I have never been at the place in my life.--She is an odd woman!--But

text: I never allow myself to speak ill of her , on Frank 's account ; for I do believe her to be very fond of him . I used to think she was not capable of being fond of any body , except herself : but she has always been kind to him ( in her way -- allowing for little whims and caprices , and expecting every thing to be as she likes ) .
text_tokenized: I never allow myself to speak ill of her , on Frank 's account ; for I do believe her to be very fond of him . I used to think she was not capable of being fond of any body , except herself : but she has always been kind to him ( in her way -- allowing for little whims and caprices , and expecting every thing to be as she likes ) .

text: And it is no small credit , in my opinion , to him , that he should excite such an affection ; for , though I would not say it to any body else , she has no more heart than a stone to people in general ; and the devil of a temper .
text_tokenized: And it is no small credit , in my opinion , to him , that he should excite such an affection ; for , though I would not say it to any body else , she has no more heart than a stone to people in general ; and the devil of a temper .

text: " Emma liked the subject so well , that she began upon it , to Mrs. Weston , very soon after their moving into the drawing - room : wishing her joy-- yet observing , that she knew the first meeting must be rather alarming.-- Mrs. Weston agreed to it ; but added , that she should be very glad to be secure of undergoing the anxiety of a first meeting at the time talked of : " for I can not depend upon his coming .

text: " Yes -- it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill - humour of Mrs. Churchill , which I imagine to be the most certain thing in the world . "
text_tokenized: " Yes -- it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill - humour of Mrs. Churchill , which I imagine to be the most certain thing in the world . "

text: " My Emma ! " replied Mrs. Weston , smiling , " what is the certainty of caprice ? "
text_tokenized: " My Emma ! " replied Mrs. Weston , smiling , " what is the certainty of caprice ? "

text: Then turning to Isabella , who had not been attending before--"You must know , my dear Mrs. Knightley , that we are by no means so sure of seeing Mr. Frank Churchill , in my opinion , as his father thinks . It depends entirely upon his aunt 's spirits and pleasure ; in short , upon her temper .
text_tokenized: Then turning to Isabella , who had not been attending before--"You must know , my dear Mrs. Knightley , that we are by no means so sure of seeing Mr. Frank Churchill , in my opinion , as his father thinks . It depends entirely upon his aunt 's spirits and pleasure ; in short , upon her temper .

text: To you -- to my two daughters -- I may venture on the truth .
text_tokenized: To you -- to my two daughters -- I may venture on the truth .

text: Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe , and is a very odd - tempered woman ; and his coming now , depends upon her being willing to spare him .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe , and is a very odd - tempered woman ; and his coming now , depends upon her being willing to spare him .

text: " Oh , Mrs. Churchill ; every body knows Mrs. Churchill , " replied Isabella : " and I am sure I never think of that poor young man without the greatest compassion .
text_tokenized: " Oh , Mrs. Churchill ; every body knows Mrs. Churchill , " replied Isabella : " and I am sure I never think of that poor young man without the greatest compassion .

text: To be constantly living with an ill - tempered person , must be dreadful .
text_tokenized: To be constantly living with an ill - tempered person , must be dreadful .

text: It is what we happily have never known any thing of ; but it must be a life of misery .
text_tokenized: It is what we happily have never known any thing of ; but it must be a life of misery .

text: What a blessing , that she never had any children !
text_tokenized: What a blessing , that she never had any children !

text: Poor little creatures , how unhappy she would have made them ! "
text_tokenized: Poor little creatures , how unhappy she would have made them ! "

text: Emma wished she had been alone with Mrs. Weston . She should then have heard more : Mrs. Weston would speak to her , with a degree of unreserve which she would not hazard with Isabella ; and , she really believed , would scarcely try to conceal any thing relative to the Churchills from her , excepting those views on the young man , of which her own imagination had already given her such instinctive knowledge .
text_tokenized: Emma wished she had been alone with Mrs. Weston . text: But at present there was nothing more to be said .
text_tokenized: But at present there was nothing more to be said .

text: Mr. Woodhouse very soon followed them into the drawing - room .
text_tokenized: Mr. Woodhouse very soon followed them into the drawing - room .

text: To be sitting long after dinner , was a confinement that he could not endure .
text_tokenized: To be sitting long after dinner , was a confinement that he could not endure .

text: Neither wine nor conversation was any thing to him ; and gladly did he move to those with whom he was always comfortable .
text_tokenized: Neither wine nor conversation was any thing to him ; and gladly did he move to those with whom he was always comfortable .

text: While he talked to Isabella , however , Emma found an opportunity of saying , " And so you do not consider this visit from your son as by any means certain .
text_tokenized: While he talked to Isabella , however , Emma found an opportunity of saying , " And so you do not consider this visit from your son as by any means certain .

text: I am sorry for it .
text_tokenized: I am sorry for it .

text: The introduction must be unpleasant , whenever it takes place ; and the sooner it could be over , the better . " " Yes ; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays . Even if this family , the Braithwaites , are put off , I am still afraid that some excuse may be found for disappointing us .
text_tokenized: The introduction must be unpleasant , whenever it takes place ; and the sooner it could be over , the better . " " Yes ; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays . Even if this family , the Braithwaites , are put off , I am still afraid that some excuse may be found for disappointing us .

text: I can not bear to imagine any reluctance on his side ; but I am sure there is a great wish on the Churchills ' to keep him to themselves .
text_tokenized: I can not bear to imagine any reluctance on his side ; but I am sure there is a great wish on the Churchills ' to keep him to themselves .

text: There is jealousy .
text_tokenized: There is jealousy .

text: They are jealous even of his regard for his father .
text_tokenized: They are jealous even of his regard for his father .

text: In short , I can feel no dependence on his coming , and I wish Mr. Weston were less sanguine .
text_tokenized: In short , I can feel no dependence on his coming , and I wish Mr. Weston were less sanguine .

text: " " He ought to come , " said Emma .
text_tokenized: " " He ought to come , " said Emma .

text: " If he could stay only a couple of days , he ought to come ; and one can hardly conceive a young man 's not having it in his power to do as much as that .
text_tokenized: " If he could stay only a couple of days , he ought to come ; and one can hardly conceive a young man 's not having it in his power to do as much as that .

text: A young _ woman _ , if she fall into bad hands , may be teazed , and kept at a distance from those she wants to be with ; but one can not comprehend a young _ man _ 's being under such restraint , as not to be able to spend a week with his father , if he likes it .
text_tokenized: A young _ woman _ , if she fall into bad hands , may be teazed , and kept at a distance from those she wants to be with ; but one can not comprehend a young _ man _ 's being under such restraint , as not to be able to spend a week with his father , if he likes it .

text: " One ought to be at Enscombe , and know the ways of the family , before one decides upon what he can do , " replied Mrs. Weston .
text_tokenized: " One ought to be at Enscombe , and know the ways of the family , before one decides upon what he can do , " replied Mrs. Weston .

text: " One ought to use the same caution , perhaps , in judging of the conduct of any one individual of any one family ; but Enscombe , I believe , certainly must not be judged by general rules : _ she _ is so very unreasonable ; and every thing gives way to her . " " But she is so fond of the nephew : he is so very great a favourite . Now , according to my idea of Mrs. Churchill , it would be most natural , that while she makes no sacrifice for the comfort of the husband , to whom she owes every thing , while she exercises incessant caprice towards _ him _ , she should frequently be governed by the nephew , to whom she owes nothing at all . " " My dearest Emma , do not pretend , with your sweet temper , to understand a bad one , or to lay down rules for it : you must let it go its own way . I have no doubt of his having , at times , considerable influence ; but it may be perfectly impossible for him to know beforehand _ when _ it will be . "
text_tokenized: " One ought to use the same caution , perhaps , in judging of the conduct of any one individual of any one family ; but Enscombe , I believe , certainly must not be judged by general rules : _ she _ is so very unreasonable ; and every thing gives way to her . " " But she is so fond of the nephew : he is so very great a favourite . Now , according to my idea of Mrs. Churchill , it would be most natural , that while she makes no sacrifice for the comfort of the husband , to whom she owes every thing , while she exercises incessant caprice towards _ him _ , she should frequently be governed by the nephew , to whom she owes nothing at all . " " My dearest Emma , do not pretend , with your sweet temper , to understand a bad one , or to lay down rules for it : you must let it go its own way . I have no doubt of his having , at times , considerable influence ; but it may be perfectly impossible for him to know beforehand _ when _ it will be . "

text: Emma listened , and then coolly said , " I shall not be satisfied , unless he comes . "
text_tokenized: Emma listened , and then coolly said , " I shall not be satisfied , unless he comes . "

text: " He may have a great deal of influence on some points , " continued Mrs. Weston , " and on others , very little : and among those , on which she is beyond his reach , it is but too likely , may be this very circumstance of his coming away from them to visit us . "
text_tokenized: " He may have a great deal of influence on some points , " continued Mrs. Weston , " and on others , very little : and among those , on which she is beyond his reach , it is but too likely , may be this very circumstance of his coming away from them to visit us . "
